To secure quick transmission, telegrams should be marked Via Eastern.

div.head: Peninsular and Oriental S. N. Company.
div.p: Berths can be definitely engaged as if the voyage were commencing at Port Said. Plans can be seen at the Offices of the Company's Agents.

The through Steamers for Marseilles, Gibraltar, Plymouth and London are intended to leave Port Said after the arrival of the 11 a.m. train from Cairo, every Monday. A steam tender will meet the train to convey passengers to the ship.
The Brindisi Express Steamer leaves Port Said directly the Indian Mails arrive. Passengers can go on board the evening before.
The express steamer usually reaches Brindisi on Wednesday afternoon, the special train starting at 8 p.m. and arriving in London at the very convenient hour of 4.56 p.m. on Friday.
The combined Sea and special train fare is 22.9.11 Port Said to London via Brindisi or via Marseilles.
Passengers having paid full fare in one direction are allowed an abatement of 25 per cent. on returning within 12 months.
In addition to the above regular weekly service there are sailings about twice a fortnight of 5,000 and 7,000 tons steamers to London, calling at Malta or Marseilles.
TO THE EAST.

The Mail Steamers leave Suez for Aden and Bombay every Wednesday, and for Australia and China every alternate Wednesday. A steamer leaves for Calcutta, fortnightly, and another for Japan. Passengers can embark at Port Said.
For all further information apply to the Company's Agents,
Messrs. THOS. COOK & SON (Egypt) Ltd. CAIRO.
GEORGE ROYLE, Esq. PORT-SAID.
Messrs. HABELDEN & Co. ALEXANDRIA.
F. G. DAVIDSON, Superintendent P. & O. S. N. Company in Egypt SUEZ.

Fast steamers leave Alexandria every Saturday at 6 p.m., and Port Said every Sunday at 6 p.m., for JAFFA (for Jerusalem), CAIFFA (for Nazareth), BEYROUT (for Damascus), TRIPOLI, ALEXANDRETTA, MESSINA, continuing in alternate weeks to LARNACA and LIMASSOL (Cyprus).

div.head: DEATH.
div.p: ADAMSON--On December 11th, at Hagar Nawatich, Alexandria, Nancy Newall, the dearly loved child of Arthur and Nancy Adamson, aged 1 year and 15 days.

div.head: The Egyptian Gazette
div.p: The English Daily Newspaper, Established 1886. Editor and Manager - - R. Snelling
Price : ONE PIASTRE TARIFF.
TUESDAY, DECEMBER 12, 1905.
The Liberal Cabinet.

Our telegrams from London this morning show that the general impression at home is that Sir Henry Campbell-Bannerman has made an excellent choice in his selection of the Cabinet. The making of a Cabinet is a most fascinating occupation for those who are not personally concerned in it. Thousands of "arm-chair politicians" have lately been employing their dearest energies in considering what they would do if they were in the place of Sir Henry Campbell-Bannerman, and in placing their opinions with what eloquence they can muster before their admiring, contumacious, or contemptuous friends.

For one man, however, the making of a Cabinet, instead of being a sweet agony of confident toil, is a task beset with difficulties and dangers. That man, we need hardly say, is the Carpenter-in-Chief. For many years he has delighted in the comparatively irresponsible delight of criticising the work of the Government manufacturer. His keen eye has been fixed on the warping of the other's wood, his sharp tongue devoted to pointing out the flaws of his design. The rival has now laid down his tools. "see if you can make a better job of it," he remarks. Thus suddenly faced with the necessity of becoming a Cabinet-maker on his own account, the newcomer can claim momentary sympathy from the fellow-workmen who love him least, and the opponents who watch him with an eye for his misdeeds.

Consider what a Cabinet really is. The depository, first of all, of the plans of Government, where are to lie stored the ideals of a party--if it be so fortunate as to possess any--and its favorite recipes for bringing peace and prosperity to the land. So far its construction seems easy enough. But when we remember that many of these ideals and recipes are not shared by the whole party, but have to be recognised as the peculiar possession of one member or one group of members, then we arrive at the second and more troublesome purpose of a Cabinet. The method, that is to say, of rewarding honorable gentlemen for their arduous service during weary days and wearier nights in the place of detention known as the House of Commons. Like the Roman soldiers worn out by long campaigns and eager for higher pay and respite from oppression, they show their scars and ask sternly--or perhaps as roaringly gentle as a sucking dove--for the share of glory they have earned.

How to leave niches for the most insistent as well as for those who say little but can do much that is unpleasant in the event of neglect; how to combine this minor necessity with the greater responsibility of leaving ample space for the larger and more practical schemes concerning the legislation and administration of an Empire--these are the problems which have confronted the new Cabinet maker, Sir Henry Campbell-Bannerman, during the past week.

For the benefit of the Empire,--it must be hoped that the new Cabinet will be as strong as the maker can make it. The government of the kingdom demands, and should receive, first attention. That is the greatest matter with all of us. In the long run it is the greatest consideration even for the mere party man. No party can be made strong and popular wich places the claims of individuals before the call of patriotism. On the other hand, we are afraid no party can gain a due measure of strength if its leader chooses his Cabinet from the men who are intellectually most competent. But as our telegrams state that even the political opponents of the new Ministry admit the excellence of the selection, it is to be presumed that Sir Henry's selection is the best that could be made.

div.head: EDEN PALACE HOTEL, CAIRO.
div.p: Noted for its excellent cuisine.
Electric Light, Lift.
Special terms for officers of the Army of Occupation and Government Officials.

div.head: THE NEW CABINET. "GOOD AND CAPABLE.”. MR. BALFOUR INDISPOSED
div.p: (Gazette's Special Service).
London, Monday. Dec. 11.

The composition of the new Ministry is generally held in political circles to be a clever one, and especially good for election purposes. The presence of Sir Edward Grey, Lord Crewe, and Mr. Haldane will afford security of a programme of moderate and wise reform. Lord Rosebery has been quite isolated. The new Lord Chamberlain will be Earl Spencer's bro-ther, the Rt. Hon. R. C. Spencer, who will receive a peerage.
London, December 11

It is agreed on all sides that Sir Henry Campbell Bannerman has enlisted the Cabinet from the strongest members of the party, with the exception of Lord Rosebery. Even Unionists admit that it is good and capable.
The Ministers will hold the first meeting of the Cabinet in a few days in order to fix the date of the elections. Mr. Balfour is indisposed. His sleep is troubled by internal pains.
(Reuter)
London, December 11.
The new Ministers have all taken possession of their portfolios, Mr. George Whiteley has been appointed Chief Government Whip.

div.head: SPEECH BY LORD ROSEBERY.
div.p: London, December 11.

Presiding at the Council of the Liberal League, Lord Rosebery congratulated Sir Henry Campbell-Bannerman upon having obtained the reward of strenuous hard work. He said that we might now expect financial economy and a strong, dignified foreign policy, and might hope to see an army once more. Nobody outside a lunatic asylum believed that Home Rule would be introduced during the next parliament. It was the duty of the Government to maintain the unity of the Free Trade parly, but they must be entirely independent of the Irish vote.
(Reuter)

div.head: MUTINY OF MANCHURIAN ARMY.
div.p: London, December 11

The “Daily Telegraph” learns from Tokio that the Russian army in Manchuria has mutinied, and, joining the Chonnchuses, has sacked Harbin, and burned the railway station and the wheat and flour storehouses. Many innocent persons have been massacred. A fierce battle is raging between the loyal troops and the mutineers.
(Reuter)

div.head: MUTINY OF WARSAW GARRISON.
div.p: Warsaw, December 11.

A hundred soldiers headed a revolutionary procession and an infantry regiment barred the way. The officer in command ordered his men to fire on the procession, but the regiment refused. The officer fled. It is reported that the whole garrison has mutinied.
(Reuter)

div.head: COUNT WITTE A REACTIONARY.
div.p: St. Petersburg, December 11.
Count Witte, realising the impossibility of a compromise, has completely gone over to the reactionary party.
(Reuter)

div.head: THE TSAR AND HIS COSSACKS.
div.p: St. Petersburg. December 11.
The Tsar, in an order of the day, warmly thanks all Cossacks for their untiring loyal services in maintaining order throughout the Empire.
The commander of the fortress of Kushk has proclaimed martial law to prevent the spread of the revolutionary propaganda.
(Reuter)

div.head: GREEK CABINET CRISIS.
div.p: Athens December 11.
M. Bonffides, a Theotokist, has been elected president of the Chamber, defeating M. Roms, Ministerialist. The Cabinet will resign.
Athens. December 11.
The Chamber of Deputies has appointed M. Bonffides as president. The Cabinet will resign.
(Havas)

div.head: THE POPE AND FRANCE.
div.p: Rome, December 11.
In his allocution at the Consistory, the Pope stated that be would speak on the question of the reparation of Church and State at the proper time.
(Havas)

div.head: SIR E. CASSEL MADE G C.M G.
div.p: London, December 11.
Sir Ernest Cassel has been promoted Knigbt Grand Cross of St Michael and St. George.
(Reuter)

div.head: Red Sea Lighthouses.
div.p: We have received a parcel of books from Mr. Karl Harold for the English keepers of the Red Sea lighthouses.

div.head: Quarantine in Turkey.
div.p: Owing to the recurrence of a case of plague' arrivals in Turkish ports from Alexandria are subjected to a medical examination.

div.head: Cairo Commercial Assessors.
div.p: The International Chamber of Commerce is engaged in revising the lists of the commercial assessors for the Cairo Mixed tribunals.

div.head: A. S. C.
div.p: We are asked by the clerk of the course to announce that the racecourse will be open for galloping to-morrow morning from 6 till 9.

div.head: S. M. S. Stein:
div.p: A number of the officers and cadets of the German training ship Stein went up to Cairo on Sunday and stopped at the Eden Palace Hotel.

div.head: The S.S Sardinia.
div.p: This steamer, having completed repairs, is now reloading a general cargo for Liverpool, and is expected to sail towards the end of this week.

div.head: Small Danco.
div.p: A small dance will be given at Mena House Hotel on Wednesday,commencing at 9 o’clock. An orchestra will perform during dinner, as well as for the dance.

div.head: Bank of Abyssinia.
div.p: Mr. McGillivray, Governor of the Faille of Abyssinia, and the other employes of the bank arrived at Djibouti on the 7th inst. and proceeded on their way to Harrar.

div.head: "Il Tempo.”
div.p: “Il Tempo,” an Italian newspaper, which is at present issued weekly, will, as from the beginning of January next, become a daily paper. The editor and proprietor is Sig. Flores-tano Quintavalle, whom we wish every success in his new venture.

div.head: Khedivial Agricultural Society.
div.p: The Khedivial Society of Agriculture has decided to appoint three new agents, two in Lower and one in Upper Egypt. A note has been forwarded to the Government requesting the necessary credits for the creation of these new posts.

div.head: Salt and Soda Co.
div.p: The sales of salt during the month of November produced L.E. 20,746.537; as against LE 23,126,220 in November, 1904 ; the total amount realised from January to November 1905 being L.E. 229 962.702 as compared to L.E. 229 816.587 during the eleven months of 1904.

div.head: Charity Performance.
div.p: On Sunday afternoon a charitable entertainment was given at the College des Freres, Koronfish, Cairo, under the auspices of M. de la Bouliniere, who was received by the "Marseillaise” on his arrival. The chief feature of the afternoon's performance was a four act drama entitled Alaff, or Le Martyr de la Siberie, a drama versified by Frere Roland of the College and played with remarkable success by the pupils. The orchestra, staging, and decorations were all admirable, and we are not surprised to hear that charity has profited by the success of the entertain-ment.

div.head: MERCHANT SEAMEN'S HOME.
div.p: A concert of more than usual interest was given in the Merchant Seamen’s Home on Friday last. The piano secured by the exertions of the Woman’s Guild of St. Andrew’s Church was handed over and used for the first time. The presentation was to have been made by Mrs. Ross, of Gordon House the president of the Guild, but she was prevented from being present by a severe chill. Mr. Ross, however ably represented his wife, and congratulated the Woman’s Guild of the Church of Scotland upon the successful issue of their labours and the handsome appearance of the piano. Turning to the men he said that the ladies in every port had a warm heart towards the sailors, and as this piano would testify, Alexandria was no exception to the rule ; indeed the Guild of St Andrew’s Church had given a very substantial token of their regard for the sailors frequenting this port Calling upon Miss Swan to hand over the piano, he took the opportunity to express the hope that those who visited the Home would spend many happy nights in company with such a nice instrument. Miss Swan then formally handed over the piano in the name of the guild for use in the Seamen’s Home, and the Rev. Hugh P. Reid thanked her for the gift and hoped that there would be no discord but much harmony and enjoyment in the entertainments in which this instrument was to play a prominent part. It was a substantial sign of the church's interest in the men. He thereafter called upon Mrs. Munro to “ hansel ” the piano, which she did with a very sweet solo. The usual concert succeeded, and it proved a most interesting and enjoyable one. An indication of the interest in the occasion was given by the numbers who simply packed the ball, and who expressed their appreciation of the fare provided in no uncertain way. The following ladies and gentlemen kindly gave their services Mrs. Munro, Mrs. Reid, Miss Davies Messrs. Byrne. Elliott Goodrich and Thom.
A vote of thanks to Mrs. Ross, who provided the tea, and to the artistes, brought a very pleasant evening to a close.
The piano is in polished oak, has a handsome appearance and a rich mellow tone, and was provided by Messrs. Paterson and Sons, of Glasgow.

div.head: SUNDAYS DISTURBANCE. PUBLIC FEELING REASSURED.
div.p: We are glad to state that there has been no repetition of Sunday's disturbances in Alexandria, and the state of public feeling is becoming somewhat reassured. Everything tends to show that the riot if it may so be characterised, was a purely spontaneous ebullition of feeling, just as was the Hamamil affair of a few years ago. when the natives made a sudden and great disturbance owing to the murder of an Egyptian policeman by a low-class Italian. If the Greek had not accidentally injured the Arab on Sunday no disturbance would have oocurred. This was the spark which, coming as it did amidst the existing state of apprehension, inflamed the passions of the populace and led to what was really nothing more serious than “a storm in a teacup.”

The state of public feeling throughout the city yesterday was still nervous, and last night a number of coffee-houses and tobacconists shops and other establishments, which are usually kept open until a late hour of the night were closed by 10 o'clock.
Last night the dangerous quarter of the Hamamil, where the worst part of the distur-bances took place on Sunday afternoon, was patrolled by a large number of police. There was no disturbance.

div.head: THE PROVINCES.
div.p: Cairo is reported to be quiet hot we regret to state-that matters in some of the provincial districts are not satisfactory, as the following statement from an Englishman, resident in the Behera province, in the neighbourhood of Damanhour, will prove. This correspondent gives us the following information :—

It is most sincerely to be hoped that the authorities will send strict injunctions to the moudirs to warn omdehs to pacify the people. The wildest rumours are current It is currently believed by the natives hereabouts that the Army of Occupation has been withdrawn and they believe that a great uprising is to take place by order of the Saltan. They read or have read to them the exaggerated stories in the Arabic papers which make them believe that the European Powers have had to submit to the Porte solely out of fear of the might of the Saltan. The Macedonian Question is keenly discussed and it is believed that the Sultan has determined once and for all to free the Ottoman Dominions of European interference. A few weeks ago the native villagers always need to salute Europeans here. Now they pass by without so doing and with a scowl. Europeans are continually being insulted, by the native youths, and yesterday, while going from my esbeh to the Delta Light Railway station, the cry against the Christians was raised at me by the village boys. They cried out, "Go on. yon Christians, we will see the matter through.” Their elders stood by and never attempted to correct them.

Reports of insults to Europeans are very frequent and I understand some Greeks close to Atfeh have been murdered. In Cairo and Alexandria the Europeans are safe, but in the villages the situation of the Christian population is very bad, for even if the moudirieh authorities had the will they would not have the requisite authority to put down any disturbance. I have noticed of late the significant increase in the amount of arms carried by the Bedouins. Youths belonging to that class of the population have of late began to go about with guns, while all the men are armed. As a matter of fact, I have seen boys about 8 years old with guns. The regulations as to bearing arms are laughed at and anybody can get back his gun from the police for a few piastres, for the police only make use of the rule that nobody but a ghaffir and the owner of an esbeh should be armed, to make a profit out of the inhabitants by seizing their guns for a few days and returning them on the payment of a small sum. The only way to overawe the people is to show them that the Army of Occupation is not a myth, and the G. 0. C. ought to order a route march at once through the villages. That would at least act as a temporary alleviation of the present unfortunate state of feeling.

div.head: FEAR OF RENEWED DISTURBANCE
div.p: It is commonly believed that there will be another disturbanoe on Sunday next, but this is very improbable, as the police have made numerous arrests among the disorderly elements of the population. On Sunday nearly 200 persons were arrested, and yesterday a similar number. Altogether up to midday to day fully 500 arrests had been made of persons who were known to have been con-cerned in the riot and of others who have used threatening language.

div.head: PRECAUTIONARY MEASURE.
div.p: As a precaution to prevent the arming of the populace the Alexandria City Police took measures to close all the shop of the gun smiths and dealers in weapons throughout the city. The demand for arms during the past fortnight has been very great, and both Europeans and natives have been purchasing revolvers, etc., in great numbers, so this step on the part of the police comes somewhat late in the day.
The date of the reopening of the gunsmiths’ shops has not yet been determined on, but they may be opened to-morrow if the authorities are sufficiently assured that the panic has subsided.

div.head: MR MARSDEN'S CONDITION.
div.p: Mr. Marsden, the sub-manager of the Anglo-Egyptian Bank, is still confined to his house owing to the injuries received by him from the mob on Sunday afternoon, but we are glad to be able to state that his wound is progressing satisfactorily, and that he hopes to be quite convalescent in a few days’ time.

div.head: AN INCIDENT.
div.p: As an amusing instance of the extraordinary fear prevailing among a portion of the Europeans on Sunday we may mention that a number of Greek sailors threw themselves into the harbour in the afternoon in order to swim to their ships. As some of them were not good swimmers and became soon exhausted, they had to be rescued from a watery grave by natives.

div.head: THE SAMANOUD AFFAIR.
div.p: The originators of the unfortunate incident at Samanoud, about which such alarming and exaggerated reports were current have met with their deserts. Eight of the men have been condemned by the Mehallah Tribunal to ten months’ imprisonment each and eight to sixteen months' imprisonment

div.head: THE NATIVE PRESS.
div.p: The mildness of the observations of Musta-pha Pasha Kamel in "Al Lewa” is significant as in the judgement of many people it is considered that the articles of our Arabic contemporary have in a great measure contributed to inflame Moslem opinion. After briefly recounting the facts of Sunday’s riot he remarks:-- As regards this (the disturbance) we again request native and foreigners alike to avoid Any quarrel or dispute, because public relations can only improve by mutual harmony. Prudent people should be 'enjoined to urge upon the uneducated classes to abstain from any demonstrations.

“Al Moayad” says :-- Our readers will notice that Europeans attach great importance to small incidents that occur in Egypt and that is why any disturbance is called a riot. It is their lack of confidence in the natives that creates this fear in their minds. The Egyptians in general hoped that the Europeans, being in this country, would come to a good understanding with the natives, especially with the Moslems, for the Egyptians are all aware that no happiness or progress can be obtained except by peace and harmony. A party of the Europeans of Egypt, however, do not understand this fact or perhaps do not want to grasp its import.

The general impression is that the Government is in a great measure to be blamed for the present state of feeling, because it has allowed "Al Lewa” to excite the populace by fanatical articles, when it would have been a very simple matter to have checked all such abuse of the liberty of the Press.

div.head: KHEDIVIAL GEOGRAPHICAL SOCIETY.
div.p: Saturday’s meeting was largely attended. Among those who listened to the eloquent tributes paid to the illustrious dead were H.E. Fakhry Pasha, M. de la Bouliniere, Mgr. Kyrillos Makarius, Coptio-Catholic Patriarch, Herr von Mohl, Piot Bey, and Ahmed Bey Zaki. Bonola Bey opened the proceedings with an account of the work done by the late Elysee Reclus. Bircher described Major von Wissman’s African discoveries. Abbate Pasha paid -homage to the illustrious de Brazza, and M. Bircher closed the series of notices of the dead with an account of Baron von Richthofen's work in the cause of geographical knowledge At the close of each notice all present rose in honor of the memory of the dead. At 4.45 p.m. the meeting terminated.
The next meeting will take place in January, when Commandant Lemaire, of the Congo Free State, will read a paper on the exploration of Central Africa.

div.head: ARMY OF OCCUPATION.
div.p: Captain F.F. Doffue, A.S C., has been granted leave of absence on private affairs.

2nd Lieut C.BG. Vernon, 2nd Battalion Royal Inniskilling Fusiliers, embarked for Cyprus to-day for the purpose of inspecting the signallers at that station. On his return he will inspect the signallers at Alexandria, finally returning to Cairo.
Major R. S. Oxley, 1st Battalion King's. Royal Rifle Corps, will embark in the Khedi-vial mail steamer El Kahira to morrow for passage to Crete, via Piraeus.
Major B.J. Lawson, A.V.D., 8.V.O. in Egypt, came down from Cairo yesterday on temporary duty, returning on completion.

div.head: MENA HOUSE.
div.p: On ’Xmas eve, (Sunday, 24th inst.) there will be a ’Xmas Tree entertainment with tea in the big dining-hall of Mens House Hotel. The Bracale Orchestra and a choir will perform during the afternoon.

There are now a hundred visitors staying at Mena House Hotel, which is about double the number of previous years. All the visitors seem to enjoy their stay there. Dancing is indulged in nearly every night, and the tennis and croquet lawns are always occupied. Excursions in the desert in sandcars or on Mena’s riding horses are quite "the thing,” and the beautiful weather we are having now keeps everyone in good spirits.

div.head: STEAMER MOVEMENTS.
div.p: The Ellerman S.S. City of Cambridge sailed on Sunday with general cargo, including 6,041 bales cotton, of which 1,679 bales ex S. S. Sardinia (1,503 bales sound and 176 bales damaged).
The Ellerman S. S. City of Khics arrived on Monday morning with general cargo and passengers from Liverpool and Malts.
The Ellerman S. S. Britannia, which sailed hence on the 28th ult., arrived at Liverpool on Monday.

div.head: FIND OF GOLD AT KHARGEH. EXTENSIVE BEDS.
div.p: Samples from the phosphate beds in the Khargeh Oasis have bean submitted to Mr. Lucas, the Government chemical expert, who reports that they contain a quantity of pyrites producing 2 dwt of gold to the ton. The residue can be used for the manufacture of sulphuric acid. The beds from which these samples have been taken are very extensive and will, no doubt prove a valuable asset.

A mining license dated July 8. 1903, cedes the Corporation of Western Egypt the right for a period of three years to prospect for metals, minerals, other then earthy minerals and precious stones, in the Oases of Khargeh, Dakhla, Farafra, and Bahariah, and during the continuance of the license the Government undertakes to grant a mining license or con-cession in the areas already mentioned, on the usual terms.

div.head: PRINCE LEOPOLD LEAVES CAIRO.
div.p: Prince Leopold of Battenberg has gone South and will be, in a few days’-time, the guest of the Sirdar, Sir Reginald Wingate Pasha, at Khartoum, till the middle of January.

div.head: A BOTANICAL CURIOSITY.
div.p: Members of the Alexandria Horticultural Society, and others who care for botanical curiosities and are unaquainted with the grotesque "Beard and Moustache Lily,” should take the present opportunity of inspecting the fine specimen of this plant to be seen in fall flower in the dep6t of Mr. Tramontina in Rosetta-road.

It is a tropical, tuberous-rooted, perennial, native of Singapore and the Malay Peninsula, belonging to a small American, Asiatic, and Australian “genua” which has a botanical order all to itself—"Taccacese”—.

The name of the plant as given to it by the distinguished botanist Dr. William Jack, of the E. India Co., sixty years ago, is ’Tacca oristata,” but it is, generally, cultivated under the name of “Ataccia oristats ’’ It is easily reproduced from its numerous tubers, like the potato ; but it cannot be successfully cultivated in the open air in the climate of Alexandria."

The tubers of a closely allied species— “Tacca pinnatifida”—found all over the old world,tropics, and Polynesia, form an important item of the daily f ood of the inhabitants, like the * Qolcas” in Egypt (known in Polynesia as the “taro’’) ; but the "Tacca” has the advantage of being a valuable medicine in cases' of dysentery and diarrhoea. It is. known to the British in the Fiji islands, where it is largely cultivated as well as indigenous, under the name of ”South Sea arrowroot.”
A. H. S.

div.head: ZIZINIA THEATRE.
div.p: The second representation of Fedora was given last night and proved another triumphant success. Once again we tender to Signa. Bellincioni our warmest congratulations on an altogether perfect performance Her superb ringing, seconded by consummate acting, is beyond praise, and leaves captions discrimination without a leg to stand upon. Such powers can only belong to a rara avis in the operatic world, of which fact none are more aware than the Alexandria audience, who, whilst her most moving passages wore in progress, were enthralled even to maintaining a strict silence; need we say more Sig. Jose Palet was again in good voice, and his interpretation of the role of Loris left nothing to be desired. His singing is very true, his manner sympathetic, and he plays up well to Signa. Bellincioni. Signa. Alice Zeppilli and Sig. Giovanni Polese also-rendered valuable assistance. The orchestration was faithfully and delicately. carried out under Sig. Zuccani’s able baton. However, it is a well known saying that he “who praises" everything praises nothing," and we feel bound to steer clear of such an impeachment by remarking once more on the altogether disproportionate length of the entr’actes Surely it is no difficult matter to shorten these protracted waits end bring the duration at the performance within reasonable limits. In the present state of things, we might almost hazard an opinion, daring as it is, that people here go to the playhouse solely for the purpose of meeting their friends.

div.head: BAND PERFORMANCE.
div.p: By kind permission of Lieut Col. C. J Mark-ham and officers, the band of the King’s Royal Rifles will play the following programme in front of Ghezireh Palace Hotel, from. 4 to 6 p.m. on Wednesday :—
1. March-LaMattchicho-Borel-CIerk.
2. Overture in the Italian style Schubert.
4. Selection--The Spring Chicken-Caryll and Monckton.
5. Russian dance - Pas des Patineurs - Godfrey.
6. Cornet solo - Serenata - Braga.
7. Selection from the ballet Dio Puppenfee - Bayer.
8. Two Step "Laughing Water" - Hager.
God save the King
THOK AN BROWN. Bandmaster.
An envelope addressed to "Any Typewriter Company, Philadelphia” was delivered at once by Uncle Sam. on the 18th October last, to the Smith Premier Typewriter Company, 28, South 8th Street.

div.head: PERSONAL AND SOCIAL
div.p: A dinner was given yesterday evening at the New Khedivial Hotel by H.B. Mahmoud Pasha Sidky, Governor of Alexandria,in honor of Bear-Admiral the Hon. Hedworth Lamb ton. The other guests- present were Captain Sir George Warrender, Bart. Flag Lieut Hugh B. Mulleneux. Mr. E B. Gould, Mr. F. G Freeman , Bear-Admiral Sir Massie Blomfield. Cap-tab Herbert J. Gedge, Mr. Lionel Sandara, Col. Hopkinson Bey, Mr. B. Williams, and Mr. Chataway.
The Earl of Londesborough will probably pay a visit to Cairo early in the New Year.
Bishop Potter, of Now York, and Mrs. Potter arrived by the Hohenzollern yesterday and are now at the Savoy Hotel.
Mr Vickers (of Vickers, Sons, and Maxim) and party also arrived yesterday and are occupying a large suite of rooms at' the Savoy Hotel.
Major Ricardo-Seavers, ex-President of the Argentine Republic, has arrived at the Tewfik Palace and intends staying a part of the season there.

Count Galazza di Santa Clara, whose name is well-known in Paris aristocratic and acade-mic circles, has returned to the Tewfik to spend the whole season. Quite a number of old clients have engaged rooms, and the hotel is likely to be full up by the end of the year.
Mrs. Crookshank Pasha left yesterday per P. and O. China for England to spend the 'Xmas holidays with her children, and returns to Egypt early in February.
Mr Norman Morrison has been appointed secretary to the Anglo-American hospital at Cairo.
Mr. T. Oliver, representative of Messrs. Maple and Co., Ltd. London, is expected to arrive at Alexandria on the 18th inst.

The following is the list of passengers who left for Upper Egypt by the train de luxe on Thursday: Mr. Drepelz and party of 12, Rev. F. and Mrs. Starry, Sir Elwin and Lady Palmer, Mr. Harrison, Miss. Baird, Miss M. Kellar, Mr. Cordagli, M. Stavridis, Mr. Bacco, Birch Pasha, Mr. Dupuis, Mr. Ottanham, Said Bey Chouker, Mr. Bennet, Mr. Sagar, Mr. * Bertelli. Mr. Skynder, Hassan Bey Haasib.

The following were the passengers by the train de luxe on Saturday :—Mr. Risler, Mr. Wyndham and party of seven. Mr. Konig and party of three, Mr. George Foaden, Mr. Hoghes, Mr. Gilman, Lieut J. Bruner, Mr. Blair, Mr. Chapmen, Miss Vernon, Mr. Bird, GoL Franzini, Mr. Faber and party of two, CoL Markham and party of two, Jackson Bey, Mr. Creak, and Bimb. Purson.

The following passengers left Shallal by Cook’s P.S. Prince Abbas on Sunday Mrs., Miss M. L and Mias E M. Hogarth, Mr. L Oneto, Mme Justina C. de 0neto, Mlle A. M. Oneto, Mlle A. M.'Noceti. Mlle S. Noceti, Mlle M. B L Masini, Mme Angela M. de Silveirs, Mr. N. Noceti. Mr. T. Carida, ' Mrs F. McLeod Mathaeon, Miss V. McLeod Matheson, Master McLeod Matheson. Miss M. Osborne. Mr. C. div.head: FULL DETAILS.
div.p: London, December 5.

The marriage of Mr. P.W. Machell, Adviser to the Ministry of the Interior, Cairo, to Countess Valda Gleichen, second daughter of H.S.H. Princess Vicotr of Hohenlohe Laugenburg, took place in the Chapel Royal, St. James's Palace, to-day at 12 o'clock. His Majesty the King witnessed the ceremony. The little chapel, with its crimson hangings, was decked with white flowers and palms, and the service was fully choral. Lord William Seymour, the Hon. C.R. Spencer, Mr. Hugo Wemyss, and Mr. Victor Seymour Cochrane acted as ushers. The first member of the Royal Family to arrive was Princess Louise, Duchess of Argyll, and with her came the Duke. Shortly afterwards Her Royal Highness was joined by Princess Christian and Princess Victoria of Schleswiz Holstein. They were followed by Princess Henry of Battenberg and Princess Ena, and then came the Duke and Duchess of Connaught and Princess Patrioia. Among the other guests present were Princess Victor of Hohenlohe Langenburg, the Marquess of Bristol, the Marquess of Hartford, and the Countess Gleichen, the Austrian Ambassador, Lady William Seymour, Lady Wantage, the Hon. Mrs. Mechell, Lady Jane Lindsay, Countess Fertescue, Lady and Miss Ponsonby, Sir Frederick Stephenson, Sir Aldon and Lady Gorst, Lady Musgrave, Lady Louisa Egerton, Lady Victoria Dawnay, Viscountess Hood, Lord and Lady Middleton, Mrs. Baring, and many more.

His Majesty the King drove up to the private entrance to the Chapel in Ambassadors'-court. He was attended by Com. the Hon. Seymour Fortescue, the Hon. Sidney Greville, and Major F. Ponsonby. The King looked in excellent health, and as he walked up the aisle, without the aid of a stick, showed no signs of lameness after his recent accident. He sat during the service in a chair at the top of the centre aisle, near the chancel rails.

The bride was given away by her brother, Lt. Colonel Count Gleichen. She wote a dress of white and silver moire antique trimmed with silver embroidery ; a veil of beautiful old Brussels lace hung from the shoulders over the train, and she wore a tulle veil edged with silver over her face. Her ornaments were a diamond brooch, the gift of H.S.H. Princess Victor of Hohenlohe, Langenburg, and an antique diamond cross, the gift of the Hon. Mrs. Machell. She was followed by four children : Miss Lavinia Spencer, Miss Loelia Pnsonby, Master Derrick Heathcoat Amory, and Master Patrick Holme, who were dressed in white satin Vandyck costumes. The little girls carried bunches of lilies of the valley and wore gold chains with emerald drops, the gift of the bridegroom, while his gift to the pages were green jade and diamond links.

The ceremony was performed by the Archbishop of Canterbury, assisted by the Chaplain in waiting. Before the entrance of the bride the St. Anne's fugue by Bach was played and as she walked up the aisle the Wagner Chorale "Wachat Ant" was sung. A short but impressive address was given by the Archbishop and during the signing of the register Brahm's anthem "How lovely is thy dwelling place" was sung and the "Meistersinger" march was played as the bride and bridegroom left the chapel. The bridegroom was supported by the Hon. Harold Willoughby as "best man."

There was no reception after the wedding as H.S.H. Princess Victor of Hohenlohe Langenburg had held one the previous afternoon in the Armoury, St. James's Palace. Later in the day Mr. and Lady Valda Machell left London for Wollaton Hall, Nottingham, lent by Lord and Lady Middleton, where the honeymoon will be spent. Lady Valda Machell's going away costume was of pale blue cloth with a pale blue moire hat edged with a band of fur and trimmed with an ostrich plume. She also wore a long white cloth coat trimmed with velvet and fur and a Russian sable boa, the gift of Lady Mount Stephen. H.S.H. Princess Victor of Hohenlohe Langenburg wore a gown of amethyst velvet with a bonnet of violets and old lace and a sable boa. Countess Feodora Gleichen wore peach-coloured crepe de chine with a violet velvet hat and a palerina and muff of stone marten. Countess Helena Gleichen wore a white cloth costume with a toque pelerine and muff of cormorant. The Hon. Mrs. Machell wore grey corded silk trimmed with chiffon, velvet and old Brussels lace, and a white chiffon bonnet trimmed with Brussels lace and an ostrich feather.
SOME OF THE PRESENTS.

Many presents were given to the bride by members of the Royal Family. The King and Queen gave an Indian shawl and a beautiful brooch with a large hexagonal amethyst in the centre, surrounded by eight pearls, between each of which were set two small diamonds. The gift of the Princess Royal was a large heartshaped mirror in a frame with a design of birds and roses, and the name "Valda" engraved at the top. An amethyst and diamond pendant was given by the Princess Victoria of Wales. From it depended little chains of platinum, studded with pearls, and finished with amethyst drops. The Duke and Duchess of Connaught gave a pair of three-branch silver candelabra of Queen Anne design ; Prince and Princess Christian, a glass topped Sheraton table ; the Princess Victoria of Schleswig-Holstein, Henry of Battenberg, a pearl horseshoe brooch, with "Good Luck" in diamonds in the centre ; and the Duchess of Albany, a Sheraton book table. From Princess Frederics of Hanover came a silver basket ; from the Prince of Hohenlohe Langenburg, a gold flexible bracelet, studded with diamonds ; the Hereditary Prince and the Princess of Hohenlohe Langenburg and the Princess of Leiningen, a jade umbrella handle ; Prince Francis of Teck, a pair of silver salt collars ; Prince and Princess Alexander of Teck, a green brocade screen with pictures depicting country life ; and from the Khedive, a pearl and diamond collar

The bride's presents also included. From the bridegroom, a diamond and ruby bracelet and a diamond and ruby ring ; from Princess Victor of Hohenlohe Lagenburg, a silver fitted dressing case and a diamond brooch ; Count Gleichen, Countess Feodora Gleichen, and Countess Helena Gleichen, jointly a diamond and ruby hair ornament in a scroll and leaf design, that can be used also as a necklace ; Countess Feodora Gleichen, bronze statue by herself of Artemis ; Countess Helena Gleichen, a landscape in oil with sheep grazing, painted by herself ; the Hon. Mrs. Machell, a diamond cross and ring ; Lord and Lady William Seymour, a brooch of fine opal ; the Earl and Countess of Canwilliam, silver candlesticks ; the Ladies Katherine and Beatrics Meade, silver salver ; Earl Spencer, silver hot water jug ; Lady Alfred Page, Sevres tea service ; Lady Brassey, cardcase with watch ; the Marchioness of Bristol, feather fan ; Dowager Lady Penrhyn, silver inkstand ; Lady Victoria Dawnay, silver poached egg spoon ; Lord and Lady Mount Stephen, diamond necklace in Empire wreath design with true lover's knots ; the Ranee of Sarawak, enamel and opal necklace ; Lord and Lady Harlech, crocadile writing case ; Lady Ashburton, Mexican onyx umbrella handle ; Lady Delamere, gold pocket mirror ; the Countess of Antrim, totoiseshell and ivory frame ; the Hon. C.R. and Mrs. Spencer, sapphire and diamond bracelet ; Viscount and Viscountess Hood, enamel and turtoiseshell umbrella handle ; Lady Louise Loder, green leather bag ; Captain and Hon. Neville Lytton, picture ; Miss Magdalen Ponsonby, gold bangle with inscription "From the Sr. James' Sisterhood, 1905" ; the Earl and Countess of Londesborough, case of gold safety pins ; the Jon. W.F.D. and Lady Esther Smith, aquamarine and enamel pendant ; Lady Sarah Spencer, cheque ; the Countess of Dartmouth, en tout cas ; Lady Wantage, fire opal and diamond pendant ; Mr. and Mrs. Charles Hunter, Eighteenth Century workbox ; Sir Philip Burne-Jones, Browning's poems ; Mrs. Bisschoffsheim, gold cup presented by Queen Victoria to Mlle Daverger in 1861 ; the Dowager Marchioness of Bath, white sun umbrella ; Lady Jane Lindsay, two silver sauce boats ; the Earl and Countess of Level and Melville, a fan ; the Hon. Spencer Lyttleton, jewel box ; Sir Walter and Lady Palmer, picture by Sir Philip Burne-Jones of Countess Feodora Gleichen at work in her studio at St. James's Palace ; Lord and Lady Burgholere, address book ; Sir Rennell and Lady Rodd, old brass Swedish sconces ; Lady Alice Egerton, silver cigarette case ; and Lord Kenyon, pearl and enamel brooch.

The Austrian Ambassador gave the bride two silver salt cellars ; Princess Bismarck, a tea service ; the Earl of Cromer, a silver coffee pot ; the Countess of Cromer, an enamel bracelet ; the Archbishop of Canterbury, George Meredith's poems ; the Duchess of Sutherland, a chased silver ring box ; the Earl and Countess of Yarmouth, Russian enamel box ; the Marquis of Abergavenny, fine silver bowls and vases ; the Sirdar and Lady Wingate, silver milk jug ; the Marquis and Marchioness of Hertford, ruby and diamond ring ; the Rev. Lord Victor and Lady Seymour, carved oak cupboard ; the Duchess of Grafton, enamel and diamond hat pin ; the bridegroom's colleagues in the Egyptian service, enamel, diamond, and amethyst necklace and brooch ; English officials in the Ministry of the Interior, Egypt, silver sarlver ; the Countess Hoyos, gilt jardiniere ; the Duke of Grafton, carved Venetian table ; Prince and Princess Dolgorouki, electric reading lamp ; the Earl and Countess Waldegrave, Lowestoft bowl ; Sir Rudolph Slatin, three bronze jars ; the Marchioness of Hamilton, a fan ; the Earl and Countess Beauchamp, Greek ivory seal ; the Countess of Kenmare, "Obiter Dicta" ; the Countess Fortescue, Mrs. Birkbeck, and Mrs. Heathcoat-Amory, antique escritoire ; Earl Fortescue, driving whip ; Mrs. Murray Guthrie, green cushion in leather case ; Lord and Lady Frederick Fitzroy, silver dish warmer ; and Lady Edward Cavendish, a crystal and amethyst hat-pin.

The bridegroom's presents included : From the bride, a diamond pin and a gold matchbox ; the Hon. Mrs. Machell, an antique gold cup on bronze stand, given by Charles the Second to Archbishop Sterne, in the original leather case ; Princess Victor of Hohenlohe-Landenburg, silver table knives ; Countess Feodora Gleichen, dessert knives and forks ; Countess Helena Gleichen, carriage clock ; the Duchess of Buckingham and Chandos, reproduction in gold of palm leaf cup recently discovered at Mycenae ; Sir William Garatin, cigar-box ; Sir Eldon Gorat, antique vases ; Lady Gorat, book ; Major F. Gore Ainley, clock ; Lady Anne Blunt, books ; Mahomed Bey Mahmoud, silver tea service ; Sir John and Lady Maxwell teaspoons ; Coles Pacha and Mrs. Coles, asparagus tongs ; the Dowager Countess of Canarvon, gold pencil case ; Earl and Countess Granville, books ; Lady Beatrice Stanley, letter weigher ; Major-General Sir Henry Colvile, spirit bottles ; and Captain Ralph Yorke, a pair of candlesticks.

div.head: HIS EGYPTIAN CAREER.
div.p: The Egyptian career of Sir Clinton Dawkins is sketched by the "Times" in the following passage in its obituary notice :--

In 1895 he was liberated from this doubtful post, and took the appointment of Under Secretary for Finance in Egypt previously held by Sir Alfred Milner and Sir Eldon Gorst. The history of the next three years he himself has written in the appendix to the ninth edition of his friend's book on "England in Egypt." They were years of crisis, and his part in them was brilliantly played. The statistics of revenue and expenditure tell their own story : the former rose from L.E. 10,698,023 in 1895 to L.E. 11,624,000 in 1898, and the latter from L.E. 9,637,900 to L.E. 10,248,000, the surplus in the last year being no less than L.E. 1,376,000. It would have been much greater had not a sum of L.E. 1,700,000 been spent in three years on the reconquest of the Sudan and the laying of railways--a permanent asset. Clinton Dawkins was the moving spirit of the Egyptian Treasury at a time when necessary expenditure and international interference were at their highest point. Those were days before the "entente," when French politicians still thought it their highest duty to thwart English arrangements for the wuiet government and the industrial development of Egypt. In spite of them, the Assouan dam was founded, and the powere of barbarism broken at Omdurman.
HIS CITY CAREER
The following criticism of the City career of Sir Clinton is from the same newspaper :--

Dawkins was often in a commanding position in the firm, which, at that moment, was not very popular in the City of London ; and it was therefore rather an unfortunate time for a man hitherto unconnected with the City to enter on his new task. Dawkins, whose work had been chiefly Government finance, in which he showed himself a master, was not altogether successful in adapting himself to the ways and habits of thought which characterise that remarkable body of shrewd and experienced men of business who constitue "the City." Those who knew him best, however, were of opinion that, if his career had not been cut short, he would have succeeded in suiting himself to his environment. He was in no sense responsible for the new policy "combines," especially to the Atlantic Shipping Trust ; but he had much to do with the details of some of them, and he helped to push several schemes for electric traction, and gave evidence as to London railways before a Parliamentary committee in 1901.
HIS BREAKDOWN
The "Times" remarks :--

The career which has thus prematurely closed was one of the most varied and successful of modern times. To have passed from Oxford into the Civil Service, as first on the list, to have been transferred from the India Office to the Treasury and at once promoted to be private secretary to the Chancellor of the Exchequer, to habe thence gone to Peru as manager of the Peruvian Corporation, then to India as Financial Member of Council, then to have been made a partner in the richest of Anglo-American business houses, and to have incidentally acted as chairman of a committee which led directly to the modern reform of the War Office--that a man should have done and been all this by the time he was entering the forties is an astonishing record. Physically strong as Clinton Dawkins used to be, this swift succession of high and responsible posts was too much for him. His heart began to fail a year or two ago. This last spring he had to cease for a time from work ; but his rest at Cadenabbia (where he stayed in company with his close friend Lord Milner) was ruined by bad weather, and, though he rallied for a while during the summer, the recovery was not real. A Parisian doctor seemed to do him good for a time, but the amendment was fallacious and the attempt to return to his work had disastrous results.

div.head: THE LATE CAPT. MEYRICKE.
div.p: The funeral of Captain Meyricke, late of the Egyptian Army, took place this day week at Ludlow, Shropshire.

The inquest upon the late Captain, who died from the result of injuries received while riding in a steeplechase at Aldershot, was held at the Cambridge Hospital on Saturday week by Mr. W.E. Foster, coroner for North Hants. A brother officer of Captain Meyricke expressed some indignation concerning the distorted and incorrect reports which had appeared in the Press concerning the accident and hoped that publicity would be given to the true facts. The statement that the horse which Captain Meyricke was riding bolted with him into a wood was absolutely without foundation. The evidence showed that he was riding his own horse, Wych Elm, in the Open Military Steeplechase on Wednesday at the Aldershot Autumn Meeting. He was riding last in the field, and on reaching the first fence the horse ridden by Lieutenant Sherrard, R.F.A., immediately in front of him, momentarily hesitated in taking the jump and swerved in the air, with the result that it collided with Wych Elm and both came to the ground, the riders being thrown. Captain Meyricke fell underneath his horse and received injuries to his head which caused concussion of the brain, from which he died next day in the Cambridge Hospital, without recovering consciousness. A verdict of accidental death was returned

div.head: CORPORATION OF WESTERN EGYPT. REPORT OF THE DIRECTORS
div.p: The directors present herewith to the Shareholders their Report and Balance Sheet for the period dating from the incorporation of the Company to the 30th September, 1905, accompanied by the Auditors' Report in compliance with the requirements of the Companies Act, 1900. The above period is short of a full financial year, but completes and important stage of the Company's operation, and is a convenient date for summarising the position of the Company's affairs, which, as no prospectus has been issued, the Directors consider the Shareholders will desire to have placed before them with as little delay as possible.

The task entrusted to the Directors has comprehended the direction of distinct undertakings, namely, the cultivation and the sale of irrigated lands, the boring of wells, the construction of the Railway from the Nile to Khargeh, and the exploitation of the earthy and other minerals of the Western Oases--all these several undertakings being interdependent and contributory to the successful working of the whole.

The operations of the Corporation are, in the opinion of the Directors, calculated to prove highly remunerative to Shareholders, by bringing about a state of prosperity, which competent observers of the conditions obtaining in the Western Oasis of Egypt have long recognised as practicable, and which will result in the repeopling of the large areas comprised in the Corporation's Concessions, and render the communities dwelling therein not as at present, merely self-sustaining, but capable of the large production of commodities suitable for exchange with those of Western Europe.

While assured of the public utility of their work, and of the beneficial results which must accrue from a policy so conclusive to the prosperity of the Western Oases and the country at large, the Directors are no less assured of the continuance of the benevolent assistance of the Egyptian Government, which hitherto has been extended both spontaneously and upon occasion when it has been invoked.

With a view to economy by a judicious and discriminating selection, both of personnel and material, the Chairman and three Directors visited Egypt in the early part of the year to study local conditions and confer with the Government and with the Local Board. As the result of this visit and of subsequent deliberation, they have placed the construction of the Nile--Khargeh Railway under the supervision of Messrs. Kincaid, Waller, Manville and Dawson, Civil Engineers, and have entered into an agreement with Messrs. Lake and Currie for their retention as Consulting Engineers in London in connection with the water-boring operations and the exploitation of the earthy and other minerals of the Oases. They have also appointed as General Manager in Egypt Mr. W.T.C. Beckett, M. Inst., C.E., who has left the service of the Bengal-Nagpur Railway (in the course of his connection with which he had acted in the capacities of Chief Engineer and of General Manager), to take up this appointment, and have placed the operations in the Oases in the immediate charge of Mr. H.J.L. Beaduell, F.G.S., F.R.G.S., an official of ripe experience, intimately acquainted with the Oases, where he has served the Egyptian Government for a term of some nine years. The duties devolving upon Secretary of the Local Board being somewhat more than secretarial, they have selected to fill that post Mr. Edward J. Scott, late District Commissioner and Political Officer in Nigeria, a Colonial official of considerable experience. The Directors are confident that these appointment will favorably commend themselves to the Shareholders.

Considerable care has been exercised in the selection of the suboridnate staff, who have been provided with the latst and best equipment. For the working of the American steam drilling plant, experienced drillers have been brought over the United States to supervise each machine ; but the Consulting Engineers report that in succeeding seasons, when extensive boring operations are continued on the tested areas, "one drill foreman will easily control from three to four machines, each machine being run solely by native mechanics and labour," thus reducing the cost of boring.

The Egyptian Government determined that at least two-thirds of the Share Capital of the Corporation should be Working Capital ; and that no Shares were to be issued as fully or partly paid up. The balance covers payment for the land grants, railway, mineral and other rights granted by the Government, and the plant, machinery and other benefits existing as the result of the exploratory work effected by several expeditions, and covers also the preliminary and other expenses (exclusive of costs of registration) incidental to the formation of and the providing of Working Capital for the Corporation.

The accounts show the Corporation to occupy a strong financial position. The final call of 5s per share, that was due on the 15th June last, was postponed, and will not be called except upon three months' notice. The invested funds of the Corporation are in thirty-four securities, all of which are quoted in the London Stock Exchange Official List and have been taken into the Balance-Sheet at cost, thought the Market price represents a substantial profit. The resources of the Corporation are ample both to build the Railway to Khargeh and to successfully irrigate such large stretches of country as should ensure adequate revenue in the comparatively near future.

The Directors will cultivate cloe trading relations with the Oases, since not only will profit accrue from the actual transactions effected, but the produce dealt in will furnish additional carrying traffic for the Railway. Advantage will be taken by opening stores for the supply of the Corporation's employes to ascertain the classes of goods most in demand by the local population. Purchases of dates will be made with a view to placing them upon the London and Continental markets. They are of a very high class and excellent prices (5 P.T. per lb. tin being realised last season) are obtainable in Cairo, where the dates of the Oases, brought thence in the past exclusively by the Bedouin on pack camel, always command a ready market. As the Oases are developed and their populations increase, they will afford and extensive market for British and other European goods, in the handling of which the Corporation will possess peculiar advantages. Special attention will be given to the Cairo market, with a view to meeting such of its requirements as the Oases can supply.

During the past season a detailed survey was made of a considerable portion of Central Khargeh, some 400 square kilometres in all being surveyed, the cultivable areas in which are now located and accurately mapped. An examination has also been made of this Oasis to its Northern limits, and to the South as far as Boulac.
LAND RIGHTS.

In the land rights possessed by the Corporation a primary asset is held which, apart from the prospective value of the earthy and other mineral rights, is capable of returning many times over the capital of the company. The Corporation is entitled during 30 years to take up land not exceeding 20,000 feddans per annum, i.e., 600,000 feddans of land in all, with the object of irrigating and selling the same. The large areas of land available in the Khargeh Oasis are composed of a purplish loamy clay and are similar to the ground at present cultivated in that Oasis. On the Gubari Road also, which leads from the Khargeh Oasis to the Dakhla Oasis, there are numerous tracts of very rich loamy land, quite as good as that found in the Nile Valley. The directors anticipate a considerable demand for the newly irrigated land on the completion of the railway, when it is reasonable to suppose that high prices will be realised for land in the vicinity of the line. Land in the Nile Valley has already sold at over £30 per feddan, and a reference to Lord Cromer's last Report will show that prices have still an upward tendency. Consequently no difficulty should be experienced in obtaining say up to £20 per feddan in the neighborhood of the Railway, and up to £10 in more remote districts. The Corporation will make advances to purchasers upon conditions mutually advantageous, as is done by Agricultural Banks.

Applications for considerable areas of land have already been received by the Directors, but appreciating the importance of the early sales in their bearing upon those effected subsequently, they have deferred the question pending completion of the first section of the Railway when the maximum prices obtainable can be more approximately ascertained.
EARTHY AND OTHER MINERALS.

The directors report that the results of investigations made in the Khargeh Oasis have been of a distinctly encouraging character. Aluminous deposits of vast extent have been disclosed, and these are available for the manufacture of aluminium sulphate by a simple process recommended by the Corporation's chemist, which can be undertaken by the natives alone. Numerous tanks are now being constructed for this purpose. A large sample bag of the crude material was forwarded to London and passed intact for the purpose of ascertaining its commercial value to Mr. Bertram Blount, who reported upon it, "the sample consists substantially of aluminium sulphate. It is a valuable material." With the alum deposits, the consulting engineers report that nickel and cobalt are generally found associated and these can be recovered after formation of alum, as a bye-product. In addition to these aluminous deposits phosphates have been located at El Deir in three parallel beds, and have been shown to extend both south and far to the north of that place. A sample taken from one of the beds proved to be auriferous, and further investigations are being made. These phosphates when pulverized will be available for use locally as superphosphates, a matter of considerable future importance when the large areas of land in the vicinity are brought into cultivation.
NILE--KHARGEH RAILWAY.

The railway concession granted by the Egyptian Government is for a period of seventy years, during which time the company has a monopoly of railway communication between the Valley of the Nile and the Oases. During the first twenty years of this period no other railway can be made within the area served by the line under construction without the Corporation being first offered the right to construct. The Government guarantees interest at the rate of three per cent. per annum on the cost of construction for twenty years, unless in any year the total net profit earned by the Company are sufficient to pay 3 per cent. on the total Share Capital of the Company. The interest is payable out of surplus revenues of the Oases, as defined by the Concession, over a period of twenty-five years. The Corporation has also the right to construct further Railways within the same area, upon application at any time within twenty years. The original intention was to effect a junction with the State Railway at or near Abou Shusha. Advantage, however, was taken of the willingness of the Government to widen the Hod Samhod Embankment for the purpose of carrying the Corporation's line ; and as a necessary sequence to the adoption of this route the actual point of departure from the State Railway is now made from near Abou Tish, a little north of Farshut. The directors have taken all possible steps to ensure the completion of line at an early date.
THE WATER SUPPLY.

Mr. H.J.L. Beadnell, F.G.S., F.R.G.S., the Corporation's geological expert and manager in the oases contributes a note on the water supply of the Khargeh and Dakhla oases, in which he says that the present output of water from the wells of these oases may be taken as approximately 200,000,000 cubic metres per annum. This water is sufficient to irrigate 30,000 acres, the duty being some 6,600 acres per cubic metre per second. The underground artesian supply being practically inexhaustible, the ouput at the surface may be almost indefinitely augmented, provided the wells are sunk in suitable localities and kept sufficiently far apart to avoid any appreciable reduction of the hydrostatic pressure.

The Oases lands have one great advantage over those of the Nile Valley in that they are not dependent on the time, volume, and duration of the Nile flood. With proper care and attention the output of wells remains constant, and in several instances wells, sunk thousands of years ago by the Romans and early Egyptians, are still yielding over 500 gallons a minute.

div.head: EGYPT'S REMARKABLE PROSPERITY.
div.p: In commenting on the announcement of a penny post to Egypt the "Globe" says :--A welcome announcement is made with reference to the postal service between the United Kingdom and Egypt. Hither on the rate was that applying to all foreing countries, but for some time past it has been felt that the close connection which exists between the Khedivial Government and our own, together with the growth of trade and the development of Egypt as a health resort, rendered it necessary that the high postal charges should be dimished. Accordingly, in a few days, the rate in force will be the same as that whith the colonies and dependencies of the Empire. The progress of Egypt has been continual since the British reluctantly assumed control of affairs, and the contrast between the position there to-day and what it was twenty years ago is marvellous. It is, indeed, a standing testimony to the far-seeing wisdom of our administrators that a land which was still recently bankrupt should now be able to show such satisfactory budgets. A considerable amount of capital is sunk in Egyptian enterprises, and the country may be expected to advance still further from year to year. It will, therefore, be a great advantage to that considerable number of persons who are in communication with Egypt that their correspondence is no longer to be restricted by heavy charges. Mr. Henniker Heaton has shown that a reduction in postage means no loss to the revenue. It is, in fact, rather the contrary ; the greater facilities more than compensate for the smaller profit on individual letters. Almost all the colonies of the Empire have consented to the change, and have found the advantage of it ; and although Egypt is nominally independent, the connection with England is so close that her admission to the Imperial Penny Post naturally forms another link in the chain which unites the two.

div.head: PENINSULAR AND ORIENTAL CO.
div.p: Our premier shipping company was probably never in a stronger financial position than is displayed in the rport just issued. After having proposed the distribution of 13 per cent. upon the Deferred, or the same as that paid for the four years previous, the directors were able to make a further provision for depreciation of ships of £170,000, in addition to the nominal allowance of £366,040, thus raising the sinking fund for the year to £536,040. This sum represents just over one seventh of the book value of the fleet, which now stands at £2,960,148 in the balance sheet. As the registered tonnage of the ships in service with the attendant steam tugs and tenders, amounts to just over 370,000 tons, it appears that the fleet is valued in the books at only £8 per ton, whilst in actual practice the weight of this capitalisation is reduced still further by the fact that the company possesses reserves amounting to £1,500,000. If these sums were deducted from the book value of the fleet it is brought down to under £4 per ton. These figures are, of course, only the outcome of years of patient saving, and go far to explain why the dividends are so large and well maintained.

div.head: Vade Mecum for the Homeward Bound.
TO OUR VISITORS.
div.p: The Egyptian Gazette has much pleasure in presenting to its subscribers the accompanying description of some of the many interesting routes by which they may travel homewards. Great care has been taken to arrange them as accurately and concisely as possible, and it will be found that none of them are fraught with difficulty. In choosing the route home there are several things to be considered. To begin with there is the difference in climate between Egypt and the various points at which you may arrive in Europe. This depends partly upon the month in which you leave Egypt, for Cairo in January may be a little warmer than Riviera, and possibly not so warm as Sicily, but in March it will be warmer than Rome, and more uniformly warm than many other places in Europe. Many people leave Egypt far too early in the year, for as a rule the weather in April and May is perfect. The warmest place to go to on leaving Egypt is Sicily. Some will want to take into consideration the number of days to be spent at sea, and we therefore subjoin a list showing the time occupied on each of the various routes between Egypt and the Continent of Europe.
They are as follows:--
The long sea routes--from Port Said or Alexandria to Plymouth, Southampton, London or Liverpool--occupy about 14 days. The short ones are as follows :--
Port Said or Alexandria to Brindisi : 3 days
Alexandria to Messina : 3 days
Port Said or Alexandria to Marseilles : 5 days
Alexandria to Venice and Trieste : 4 days
Alexandria to Naples : 3 days
Port Said to Genoa : 5 days
Port Said to Naples : 4 days
Alexandria to Constantinople : 4 days
Alexandria to Piraeus : 2 days
Port Said to Gibraltar : 7 days

The steamers, of the P. and O. North German Lloyd, Orient and Messageries Maritimes are the largest. The Anchor, British India, and Bibby Lines are also excellent, and their steamers are largely patronised by travellers to Egypt.
As regards the train journeys from Cairo, the shortest is that to Alexandria, without change (3 hours). That to Port Said, can now be made without change in 4 1/2 hours.

The least expensive way to England is by the Moss, Papayanni, Prince, and Westcott lines of steamers from Alexandria to Liverpool. The German Levant line has also good steamers from Alexandria to Hamburg
The most expensive but quickest through Continental routes are by P. and O. Brindisi express from Port Said, and the Austrian Lloyd Trieste-Vienna express from Alexandria.

As regards heavy luggage, it must be borne in mind that very little luggage is allowed free on the railways of Europe, but there are several good and responsible forwarding agents in Egypt who undertake at a fixed charge to deliver packages to any address in Europe.

The quickest manner of getting to Europe from Port Said is undoubtedly by the fast Mail Steamers "Osiris" and "Isis" to Brindisi. One of these leaves Port Said every week, as soon as possible after receiving the Indian mails from the great liner arrived from Bombay.

These small but comfortable ships have enormously powerful engines, and attain a very high rate of speed. They are called the "Ferry boats," having been specially built to carry the British mail from Port Said to Brindisi. If you are going straight through to England you will find the train waiting at Brindisi which will take you to Calais without changing. It has complete arrangements for sleeping and eating on board, and you should arrive in London on the fifth day from leaving Port Said.

div.head: PISA GRAND HOTEL ET HOTEL DE LONDRES
SICILY
div.p: The direct route to Sicily is by the Florio-Rubattino Co.'s steamers which leave Alexandria weekly for MESSINA, where one takes train to TAORMINA, one of the most charming and popular places on the island. Giardini is the station at which to alight, and the drive up to Taormina is most delightful, occupying about one hour.In and around the town is much to interest the visitor. The theatre is of Greek origin, but restored under the Romans. CATANIA is the starting place for the ascent of Etna and here also is a fine Cathedral. The Greek, Roman, and Saracenic remains that are found all over the island, are an endless sources of pleasure. SYRACUSE has an interesting history, having been a Greek city, which was designed by Demosthenes in B.C. 413, and taken by the Romans in B.C. 212, when Archimedes was slain - his tomb is to be seen. The cathedral was once an ancient pagan temple. PALERMO, with about 300,000 inhabitants, is the capital of the Island, and enjoys a delightful climate. Much of interest is to be found in this fine city. The Palazzo Reale is of S. Giovannia degli Eremiti with its picturesque cloisters. The Cathedral, Museum, Botanic Gardens, Villa Giulia and Royal Park are also worth a visit.

div.head: CENTRAL ITALY
div.p: The fine steamers of the North German Lloyd leave Alexandria every Wednesday during the season for Naples, the voyage being only 3 days.

NAPLES is also reached in 10 hours from Palermo by the Florio-Rubattino Co.'s steamers, which leave daily. One cannot approach Naples or leave it without wishing to explore some of its islands, besides the lovely places on its bay--Castellamare and Sorrento. The small steamer that takes you to Sorrento [you can drive too] will take you on to Capri.

From Naples to ROME is a train journey of but five hours. All who can will devote at least one week to visiting the many historical and interesting portions of the Eternal City, whose charms and beauties are too well-known to need comment here.

Leaving the Eternal City with much regret, railway journey of five hours brings you to FLORENCE, where another week can well be spent admiring the City of Flowers and its surrounding country. In Florence itself the churches and galleries are of absorbing interest, whilst the local promenades and excursions should not be omitted. The Cascine is the most attractive and fashionable promenade in Florence, whilst the Viale dei Colli, one of the finest walks in Europe, opened 35 years ago, goes winding up through the hills a distance of four miles. The most delightful excursion outside Florence is that to Vallombrosa, with its Monastery 3,300 feet above the sea level. This is made first by ordinary train from Florence to St. Ellero, thence by cogwheel railway to Saltino. The ascent through groves of oaks takes an hour, and most striking panoramas are unfolded to view.

PISA is easily reached from Florence in about 2 hours ; here there is a fine Cathedral and the Leaning Tower. A stay of at least one night should if possible be made, in order to enjoy the view from the Campanile at sunset.

VIAREGGIO. One of the most delightful places on the Italian Riviera near Pisa and on the main line from Rome to Genoa. It is a very convenient halfway house between Egypt and England, and where living is reasonable and the air and surroundings exceptionally good.

div.head: NORTHERN ITALY
div.p: GENOA (La Superba)--The most picturesque and interesting city in Italy, with the record of having one of the lowest death averages of European cities and a phenomenally equable temperature--warm in winter and deliciously cool breezes from the surrounding mountains and the Mediterranean in summer.

The patriarchal home of Italy's most ancient nobility, whose palaces, gardens, and famous collections of statuary, frescoes, and paintings, are a constant delight to thousands of travellers who annually sojourn to Genoa. Then there are the superbly decorated medieval churches containing exquisite marble columns and historical paintings, and the incomparable Campo Santo filled with its wonderful tombs.
From Genoa to Milan is a matter of only three hours by rail.

MILAN is a good centre for Northern Italy before making the tour of the Lakes. The Cathedral is the principal attraction, with its beautiful windows illustrating the History of the Bible. The public gardens and the monumental cemetery are also worth a visit.

Between Bologna and Milan and only an hour and a half from Nilan is SALSOMAGGIORE, a renowned health resort on account of its thermal springs, change trains at Borgo San Dorino and in half an hour you are at Salsomaggiore.

div.head: Gnd HOTEL DE LA VILLE, FLORENCE.
NORTHERN ITALY and THE ITALIAN LAKES.
div.p: VENICE is a 5 hours journey by rail from Milan, and one of the most delightful places imaginable to pass a quiet stay. The total absence of vehicular traffic strikes one as very strange ; no horse, cart, carriage, or bicycle is to be seen, and yet there is the sound of life at every turn. The approach to Venice from the Adriatic is unlike that of any other seaport. The town seems to be gradually, like Aphrodite, born of the sea, no hills behind, no stretches of rock, but first the tops of Campaniles appear above the horizon, then slowly the whole glittering town rises like a fairy mirage out of the calm lagoon.
Going nothwards from Milan you make the tour of the beautiful Italian lakes.
COMO, the birthplace of the younger Pliny, is reached in one-and-a-quarter hours by train by way of Monza.

Boats leave Como frequently for the other towns on the lake, which is very beautiful, and the scenery on either side going up the lake is most enchanting. CERNOBBIO is a charming spot ; then come Tremezzo, Cadenabbia, and Menaggio with the prettily situated town of Bellaggio opposite. The walk from Tremezzo along the shore of the lake to Menaggio is most enjoyable. A steam tram runs from Menaggio to Porlezza on Lake Lugano in three quarters of an hour, then steamer to Lugano in two and three quarter hours.

div.head: SWITZERLAND.
div.p: Switzerland, the heart of Europe, has been described as "A cluster of delights and grandeurs."

LUGANO is some 20 miles from Como and reached by train in one and a half hours. It has a population of 10,000 people and is charmingly situated on the Lake of Lugano, amidst lovely Italian scenery. Around it rise M. San Salvatore, M. de Caprino and M. Generoso.

LOCARNO may be reached by rail from Bellinzona in forty minutes. This pretty town, situated at the top of Lake Maggiore, has a mild climate, and is an excellent winter resort. The church Madonna del Sasso, situated above the town, is worth a visit, as it contains interesting paintings, "Entombment," by Ciseri, and "The Flight into Egypt," by Bramantion.
LUCERNE--A striking picture on the Lake of Lucerne facing the Rigi and Pilatus and the snow-clad Alps.
In and around the town the walks are charming, and the excursions to be made from Lucerne by boat, rail, etc. are very numerous.

The Lake of Lucerne abounds in delightful excursions, those to the Rigi, Pilatus, Burgenstock and Sonnenberg needing a special visit each. Other excursions on the lake can be made by steamer, and the ever-changing scenery on the trip from Lucerne to Fluelen is a source of delight to the lover of nature.

BRUNNEN, charmingly situated on the most beautiful part of the Lake of Lucerne, commands magnificent views of lake and mountain scenery. Along the Lake of Uri from Brunnen to Fluelen runs the famous Axentrasse.

A delightful excursion from Lucerne is that to ENGELBERG. Take boat to Stansstad and from Stansstad it is about 1 hour and 40 min. by Electric Railway, with delightful scenery en route. The ascent of Titlis, is made from here, and the panoramic view of the Alps is grand ; extending from Monte Rosa to the Black Forest, and from the Santis to the Matterhosn.

THE BERNESE OBERLAND.--INTERLAKEN a favourite summer resort and the best centre for making excursions in the Oberland, abounding in fine walks and views. There is a magnificent view of the Jungfrau from the Hoheweg, a fine avenue of walnut trees the chief resort of visitors. Interlaken is also not far from the famous waterfalls, Giessbach, Trummelbach, and Staubbach. Then also the glaciers of the Grindelwald and view from Murren and the Schynige Platte are sights not to be missed.

CHATEAU D'OEX. 3,500 ft. above the sea on the new Electric Railway between Montreux and Interlaken, surrounded by magnificent scenery, with pure dry air. Much frequented by English people in Summer and Winter.

div.head: GREECE AND IONIAN ISLES.
div.p: Many people visit Greece after wintering in Egypt, as it is so easily reached from Alexandria ; the climate in April is charming. The best steamers are those of he Khedivial Mail Co. and the Russian Steam Navigation Co.

If possible tourists should arrange to be in Athens for the Orthodox Easter in order to witness the Good Friday and Easter Eve ceremonies, and to be present at the dancing on the Easter Tuesday festival held at Megara for which a special train is run from Athens.
It is worth while to spend a few days in CORFU on account of the beauty of the scenery. There is also good snipe and quail shooting to be had.
